author: Ed Monk
title: Parents making 'wrong choices' on Junior Isas
text:
Parents making 'wrong choices' on Junior Isas Parents are too cautious with their children's long-term savings, leading to poor returns Falling short: Parents' best intentions could fall flat because they neglect to put their children's savings into equities. Photo: ALAMY By Ed Monk , Investment Editor 1:41PM BST 20 Oct 2015 Comments 
Too many parents are making “simply the wrong choice” when it comes to tax-free investing on behalf of their child, analysts have warned. 
Eventual returns from putting money aside in tax-free, Junior Isas are likely to disappoint because too much of the money remains in cash deposits, despite overwhelming evidence that investing in stock and shares over long periods brings far greater rewards. 
Research indicates that parents’ own caution about investing in the stock market should not extend to investments made in the name of their children. That’s because a child will typically have far longer to remain invested, leaving time for short-term falls in share prices to even out. 
Despite that, 70pc of money flowing into Junior Isas went into cash, and not shares, last year, according to HM Revenue & Customs figures.

“For the majority of Junior ISA investors, cash is simply the wrong choice and parents and grandparents should be looking to a stocks and shares Junior ISA to improve the potential returns,” said Danny Cox, a chartered financial planner for Hargreaves Lansdown, the broker. 
“Investing for new born children or grandchildren is the most popular time with nearly 30pc of our Junior ISAs being set up before the child reaches their first birthday. 
“Sensibly these parents and grandparents are recognising that over the longer term a stocks and shares Junior ISA is likely to provide a much better return than a cash Junior ISA.” 
A wealth of data has shown over generations that shares outperform other asset classes. One of the most authoritative studies is the Barclays Equity Gilt Study which tracks asset returns for more than a century.
